claim.statement: Party dispersion increases as the number of parties increases, but the effect levels off at about five parties; electoral rules have no direct impact on dispersion once the number of parties is taken into account.
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Findings sections (summary pages 1–2 of the PDF)

data.wave_or_subset: Party manifesto data for 20 parliamentary democracies covering economic and social policy dimensions
data.sample_size: Parties per system range from 2 to 13 (mean 5.4, SD 3.5)
data.access_details: CMP data are publicly available upon registration with the project website
data.notes: High inter-coder reliability noted; two-dimensional policy positions constructed via principal components analysis

method.description: The authors pool CMP manifesto data from 20 parliamentary democracies, construct two policy dimensions (economic and social) from CMP issue categories, and calculate party dispersion within each system. They then test how dispersion varies with the number of parties and electoral system characteristics using regression analysis.
steps: Collect party-level manifesto data from the CMP for 20 parliamentary democracies.
Use principal components analysis on selected CMP categories to create economic and social policy scales for each party.
Define party dispersion within each country–year as the spread of party scores on each dimension.
Measure the number of parties by (a) a 1 % seat-share inclusion rule and (b) Laakso & Taagepera’s effective number of parties.
Classify systems as two-party or multi-party and record counts from both measures.
Estimate OLS regressions of party dispersion on the number of parties, controlling for country effects and electoral system variables (district magnitude, proportional vs single-member).
Assess whether dispersion plateaus beyond five parties and whether electoral rules exert an independent effect.
method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression with country controls
method.outcome_variable: Party dispersion on economic and social policy dimensions
method.independent_variables: Number of parties (count and effective), electoral system type (proportional vs single-member), median district magnitude
method.control_variables: Country fixed effects / country-specific variance controls

results.summary: Dispersion on both economic and social dimensions is significantly greater in multi-party systems than in two-party systems. Dispersion rises with each additional party but stops increasing once a system has about five parties. After controlling for the number of parties, electoral rules no longer have a direct effect on dispersion. Regression models explain 19–31 % of the variance in dispersion.
